results.title: Crocodile
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, Christopher Parsons, Don Murray, British Broadcasting Corporation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A comprehensive treatment of saltwater and freshwater crocodiles. A ‘non-specialist’ film, it is nevertheless scientifically accurate, and takes a balanced view of this little understood and seldom loved reptile, which is now in danger of extinction. Narrated by Hugh Falkus. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Shaw, Christopher Parsons, Don Murray, British Broadcasting Corporation and Film Australia

results.title: A Prospect of Kew
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
Richard Mabey goes beyond the showpiece attractions of the Kew Gardens in Surrey to reveal how its two centuries of history and its scientific research has made it the international centre for plant conservation.

results.title: One way ticket to Hualampong
results.creator_credit: Jeanne La Chard and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
Hualampong railway station is where thousands of children arrive hoping to find jobs but are sold into the misery and degradation of slavery and sin in Bangkok’s sweatshops, factories and brothels. Many simply disappear. The fact that children are an integral part of the work force is accepted in south east Asia, but in Thailand it is a cruel and thriving business.

results.title: Down on the Factory Farm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
An examination of intensive farming methods used in Great Britain today for raising chicken, pigs and vealers. Investigates the question of increased productivity and cheaper food versus animal welfare. There is some evidence that more natural alternatives to factory farming can have much the same production levels for marginally extra cost

results.title: People out of time
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A study of the Bindubi tribe, Australian aborigines who have mastered their arid, inhospitable environment in the Great Sandy Desert by using every resource to the maximum point of refinement. Filmed on Professor Donald Thompson’s 1963 expedition. Narrated by Leo McKern, filmed by David Corke and Len McLarty, written and presented by Eric Davidson.

results.title: Lawrence of Arabia didn't come down this far
results.creator_credit: Julian Cooper and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A carpenter from England in search of his personal dream worked on a building site in Kuwait for a year. Tells the story of his adventure, and also looks in detail at Kuwait and its secret, male dominated society. Photography by Ken Lowe and edited by Graham Shipham. Narrated by Jonathan Raban.

group_works.title: Jim Pallas: electronic sculptor
group_works.creator_credit: Sue Marx and Marx Handley Productions

results.title: Jim Pallas: electronic sculptor
results.creator_credit: Sue Marx and Marx Handley Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Working Artists”.
Jim Pallas assembles fantastic sculptures which move and light up as they respond to heat, sound and motion. The film follows Pallas as he creates new pieces, describes finished work and explains the philosophy behind his art. In the final sequence, Pallas attends the unveiling of his latest work which displays intricate light patterns triggered by the movement of dancers.
results.description:

results.title: Think big
results.creator_credit: Susan Doring, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Working series”.
One of a series of films about the place of work in people’s lives. To be really successful one needs determination and hard work. Many executives put work before the family causing conflicts, but a choice has to be made. Two executives, a man and a married woman discuss their jobs.
